title-group.article-title: Bond Ratings: Are Two Better than One?

abstract.p: Why do borrowers obtain more than one credit rating for their bond issues, and what is the impact on the net borrowing cost of a second credit rating? According to a sample of general obligation bonds, state and local governments that purchase a second credit rating for new bond issues reduce their borrowing cost by 5.2 basis points if the two credit ratings are identical. In the case of a split credit rating, split-rated bonds sell at interest cost below comparable bond issues that are rated the same as the lower of the two split ratings. This suggests that most issuers can reduce borrowing costs by purchasing a second credit rating, even considering the cost of the additional rating.
